linkTarget.anchoringText: Grechka, Li, Howell, Garcia, and Wooltorton (2017) showed for the case of the Middle Bakken dolomites that microseismic events may play a role of high frequency sources for HF evaluation. For the sake of computational time 5ftvoxel was chosen. From the same observation we can conclude that all 4 clusters of Stage 19 were open. Based on seismic attributes presented in the paper (Dip and Azimuth), we present an interpretation that detectable half lengths (Xf) were approximately 65-75 ft with a reasonable height of 240-260 ft (Fig. 1).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Identified seismic anomalies crossing perforation intervals (red dots) in the Middle Bakken formation. Map view is on the left and 2-D cross section on the right. Source: Grechka et al. (2017).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Identified seismic anomalies crossing perforation intervals (red dots) in the Middle Bakken formation. Map view is on the left and 2-D cross section on the right. Source: Grechka et al. (2017).

The correlation for well #31 is a blue curve, Lacy (1997) is a black dashed curve. Static YM vs dynamic YM for the well # 31 Static PR vs dynamic PR for the well # 31

The correlation for well #31 is a blue curve, Lacy (1997) is a black dashed curve. Static YM vs dynamic YM for the well # 31 Static PR vs dynamic PR for the well # 31

Static PR vs dynamic PR for the well # 31

Lacy, (1997)
L. L. Lacy
(1997). Dynamic Rock Mechanics Testing for Optimized Fracture Designs. Paper presented at the Annual Technical Conference and Exhibition, San Antonio, TX.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Dynamic to static correlation in our study for offset well (#31) has a similar polynomial relationship (solid blue curve in Fig. 3), buta formula proposed by Lacy (1997) underestimates static modulus for ~25%(black dashed curve). A correlation for static PR is more problematic probably because micro cracks are selective slowing compressional waves even for preserved, “as received” rock samples. One should also note that ultrasonic tests on core samples are based on high-frequency sources (1 MHz) in comparison to (~10kHz) used in logging tools which can add additional error into sonic log analysis.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Comparison of PR calculated by different correlations for the offset well #31. Average PRDTC for the target interval is 0.29.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparison of PR calculated by different correlations for the offset well #31. Average PRDTC for the target interval is 0.29.

linkTarget.anchoringText: From comparison of Figures 3 and 4 we can conclude that PRDTC has a reasonable match with PR calculated from ISIP. The second observation is that PR varies ±10% for individual stages indicating minor stress shadowing. We provide one of the possible explanations for such minor stress shadowing shown below.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Calculated from ISIP Poisson’s ratio for individual stages of the well #46. Average PR is 0.28.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Calculated from ISIP Poisson’s ratio for individual stages of the well #46. Average PR is 0.28.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Such numerical artifacts may lead to inefficient well spacing and stacking decisions. In addition, we found that proppant transportation and height confinement of individual clusters are also grid size dependent. To illustrate that we compared in (Fig. 5) test runs for the same synthetic data similar to that for the well #46. We modeled one stage with 3 clusters 50 ft apart, thus the only difference between the two cases was the node size 7.5ft ×15ft and 2.5ft ×5.0ft respectively.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Proppant concentration map for a synthetic 3 clusters per stage case (warm colors for higher proppant concentrations). Node sizes of 7.5ft x 15 ft for upper map and 2.5ftx5ft for the lower one.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Proppant concentration map for a synthetic 3 clusters per stage case (warm colors for higher proppant concentrations). Node sizes of 7.5ft x 15 ft for upper map and 2.5ftx5ft for the lower one.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The proppant tends to settle faster, forming dunes and thin layers of higher proppant concentration, which may cause pitchouts as shown in Figure 6 for the test run of well #46 Stage 2 with five clusters. More importantly, with a coarse grid, the HF may be calculated artificially wider and smoother. In this case, an engineer will have an overly optimistic proppant placement scenario. The leak off is highly pressure-dependent especially in the proximity of the wellbore.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Two-dimensional cross sectional view of fractures pinch out at Stage 2 of well #46. The color represents proppant concentration, from 0 lb/ft2 (grey) to 2.0 lb/ft2 (red).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Two-dimensional cross sectional view of fractures pinch out at Stage 2 of well #46. The color represents proppant concentration, from 0 lb/ft2 (grey) to 2.0 lb/ft2 (red).

linkTarget.anchoringText: Analysis of Drilling Induced Tensile Fractures (DITF) conducted by Heidbach, Rajabi, Reiter, and Ziegler (2016) provides the number and direction of tensile fractures in (Fig. 7) for the Midland Basin and indicates E-W direction of Shmax. From the analysis of microseismic focal mechanism, Agharazi (2016) came up with anisotropy of 8% and azimuth of N1030 which we used in our model before analysis of microseismic from well #46.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Maximum horizontal stress orientation in the south portion of the Midland Basin according to World Stress Map. Inside the area of interest, the Shmax azimuth is assumed to be N1030. Sources: Heidbach et al. (2016) and Google Earth.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Maximum horizontal stress orientation in the south portion of the Midland Basin according to World Stress Map. Inside the area of interest, the Shmax azimuth is assumed to be N1030. Sources: Heidbach et al. (2016) and Google Earth.

linkTarget.bib:
Heidbach et al., 2016
O. Heidbach , M. Rajabi , K. Reiter , & M. Ziegler (2016). World Stress Map Database Release 2016. GFZ Data Services.In .

linkTarget.anchoringText: It is observed from Fig. 8 that many MS events from Stage 5 are generated around Stage 4, so we can conclude that liquid from the Stage 5 reinitiated a lot of MS in the area already stimulated by the Stage 4. The liquid is constantly trying to find the path of least resistance, so interpretation of MS events may help in identification of inefficient pad fluid leakoff. Possible losses of pad fluid preferably into the area stimulated by previous stages may also be a result of fluid migration through of highly conductive axial fracture (orange line in Fig. 8).

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Semi-stochastic DFN based on recorded MS events for the Stage 5. We marked individual MS events as dots, not connected to HF fractures as grey lines, connected to HF fractures as colored lines, and perforations as black diamonds.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Semi-stochastic DFN based on recorded MS events for the Stage 5. We marked individual MS events as dots, not connected to HF fractures as grey lines, connected to HF fractures as colored lines, and perforations as black diamonds.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The pressure dependent leakoff was calculated for the range of treating pressures from 7,000 psi to 11,000 psi and for various h/a0. The calculation results for the case of h/a0=0.4are presented at semi-log plot in Fig. 9, together with the best fit exponential curve. From the fitting equation, the pressure dependent leakoff coefficient (PDL) is 0.00047 psi−1, which is close to one we used before MS data was available for analysis – 0.0005 psi−1.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Total leakoff calculated based on generated DFN as a function of bottom hole treating pressure. In this case, h/a0 =0.4.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Total leakoff calculated based on generated DFN as a function of bottom hole treating pressure. In this case, h/a0 =0.4.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 10 shows the PDL coefficient calculated with h/a0 ranging from 0.00036 to 0.00093.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Sensitivity analysis of PDL coefficient with the change of h/a0 ratio. The base case is marked as a red diamond.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Sensitivity analysis of PDL coefficient with the change of h/a0 ratio. The base case is marked as a red diamond.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Unfortunately, as it shown in Fig. 11 due to stress shadowing effects, individual fractures tend to deflect irregularly upward or downward, leaving a portion of the near wellbore region unstimulated.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: An example of 3D Baseline fracture conductivity attribute for multistage fracturing for well #46. Baseline conductivity is provided after correction for proppant pack degradation and imperfect fracture cleanup. Side view. Toe is on the left.

formatted-caption.caption-text: An example of 3D Baseline fracture conductivity attribute for multistage fracturing for well #46. Baseline conductivity is provided after correction for proppant pack degradation and imperfect fracture cleanup. Side view. Toe is on the left.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Near wellbore axial fractures may take a significant portion of the proppant. In our simulations16.5% (56,000 lbs out of 335,000 lbs) of sand settled into axial fractures near the wellbore, see Proppant loss storage curve in Fig. 12.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Modeling result for one of the stages. Average wellhead pressure is matched against field data.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Modeling result for one of the stages. Average wellhead pressure is matched against field data.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Despite reasonable results of geomechanical modeling indicating 100% cluster efficiency for all tested stages, we ran test cases with variations of cluster designs. To show the importance of stress shadowing and engineering design, we left all pumping parameters the same except we artificially closed clusters #1 and #3 for Stages 3-14. This change resulted in more liquid and proppant available for each of three open clusters, more vertically symmetrical reservoir stimulation, better proppant placement laterally, and more conductive axial fractures (Fig. 13).

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Test simulation for well #46 with 60% cluster efficiency. Clusters 2, 4, and 5 are open. Side view. Toe is on the left.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Test simulation for well #46 with 60% cluster efficiency. Clusters 2, 4, and 5 are open. Side view. Toe is on the left.
